user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_bus_finish:
```c
void metal_linux_bus_finish(void)
{
	struct linux_bus *lbus;
	struct metal_bus *bus;

	for_each_linux_bus(lbus) {
		if (metal_bus_find(lbus->bus_name, &bus) == 0)
			metal_bus_unregister(bus);
	}
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (metal_bus_find(lbus->bus_name, &bus) == 0)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The call itself does not directly call any <string.h> routines, so the fragment shown does not by itself violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. However a violation can occur if the implementation of metal_bus_find uses string.h functions unsafely. Example violation scenario: lbus->bus_name points to a non‑null‑terminated or undersized buffer and metal_bus_find does something like strcmp(lbus->bus_name, table[i].name) or strcpy(dest, lbus->bus_name). In that case strcmp/strcpy/strlen could read or write past the bounds of the object referenced by lbus->bus_name (or the destination), violating Rule 21.17.
